scene.line: Here comes Bassanio, your most noble kinsman,
Gratiano, and Lorenzo. Fare ye well,
We leave you now with better company.

speech.speaker: SAL.
speech.line: I would have stay’d till I had made you merry,
If worthier friends had not prevented me.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Your worth is very dear in my regard.
I take it your own business calls on you,
And you embrace th’ occasion to depart.

speech.speaker: SAL.
speech.line: Good morrow, my good lords.

speech.speaker: BASS.
speech.line: Good signiors both, when shall we laugh? Say, when?
You grow exceeding strange. Must it be so?

speech.speaker: SAL.
speech.line: We’ll make our leisures to attend on yours.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: It is that—any thing now!

speech.speaker: BASS.
speech.line: Gratiano speaks an infinite deal of nothing, more than any man in all Venice. His reasons are as two grains of wheat hid in two bushels of chaff; you shall seek all day ere you find them, and when you have them, they are not worth the search.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Well, tell me now what lady is the same
To whom you swore a secret pilgrimage,
That you today promis’d to tell me of?

speech.speaker: BASS.
speech.line: ’Tis not unknown to you, Antonio,
How much I have disabled mine estate,
By something showing a more swelling port
Than my faint means would grant continuance.
Nor do I now make moan to be abridg’d
From such a noble rate, but my chief care
Is to come fairly off from the great debts
Wherein my time something too prodigal
Hath left me gag’d. To you, Antonio,
I owe the most in money and in love,
And from your love I have a warranty
To unburden all my plots and purposes
How to get clear of all the debts I owe.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: I pray you, good Bassanio, let me know it,
And if it stand, as you yourself still do,
Within the eye of honor, be assur’d
My purse, my person, my extremest means,
Lie all unlock’d to your occasions.

speech.speaker: BASS.
speech.line: In my school-days, when I had lost one shaft,
I shot his fellow of the self-same flight
The self-same way with more advised watch
To find the other forth, and by adventuring both
I oft found both. I urge this childhood proof,
Because what follows is pure innocence.
I owe you much, and like a willful youth,
That which I owe is lost, but if you please
To shoot another arrow that self way
Which you did shoot the first, I do not doubt,
As I will watch the aim, or to find both
Or bring your latter hazard back again,
And thankfully rest debtor for the first.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: You know me well, and herein spend but time
To wind about my love with circumstance,
And out of doubt you do me now more wrong
In making question of my uttermost
Than if you had made waste of all I have.
Then do but say to me what I should do
That in your knowledge may by me be done,
And I am prest unto it; therefore speak.

speech.speaker: BASS.
speech.line: In Belmont is a lady richly left,
And she is fair and, fairer than that word,
Of wondrous virtues. Sometimes from her eyes
I did receive fair speechless messages.
Her name is Portia, nothing undervalu’d
To Cato’s daughter, Brutus’ Portia.
Nor is the wide world ignorant of her worth,
For the four winds blow in from every coast
Renowned suitors, and her sunny locks
Hang on her temples like a golden fleece,
Which makes her seat of Belmont Colchis’ strond,
And many Jasons come in quest of her.
O my Antonio, had I but the means
To hold a rival place with one of them,
I have a mind presages me such thrift
That I should questionless be fortunate!

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Thou know’st that all my fortunes are at sea,
Neither have I money nor commodity
To raise a present sum; therefore go forth,
Try what my credit can in Venice do.
That shall be rack’d, even to the uttermost,
To furnish thee to Belmont, to fair Portia.
Go presently inquire, and so will I,
Where money is, and I no question make
To have it of my trust, or for my sake.

scene.scenelocation: Belmont. A room in Portia’s house.

stagedir.dir: Enter Portia with her waiting-woman, Nerissa.

scene.line: How now, what news?

speech.speaker: SERV.
speech.line: The four strangers seek for you, madam, to take their leave; and there is a forerunner come from a fift, the Prince of Morocco, who brings word the Prince his master will be here tonight.

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: If I could bid the fift welcome with so good heart as I can bid the other four farewell, I should be glad of his approach. If he have the condition of a saint, and the complexion of a devil, I had rather he should shrive me than wive me.
Come, Nerissa. Sirrah, go before.
Whiles we shut the gate upon one wooer, another knocks at the door.

stagedir.dir: Enter Bassanio with Shylock the Jew.

speech.speaker: BASS.
speech.line: This is Signior Antonio.

speech.speaker: SHY.
speech.line: How like a fawning publican he looks!
I hate him for he is a Christian;
But more, for that in low simplicity
He lends out money gratis, and brings down
The rate of usance here with us in Venice.
If I can catch him once upon the hip,
I will feed fat the ancient grudge I bear him.
He hates our sacred nation, and he rails
Even there where merchants most do congregate
On me, my bargains, and my well-won thrift,
Which he calls interest. Cursed be my tribe
If I forgive him!

speech.speaker: BASS.
speech.line: Shylock, do you hear?

speech.speaker: SHY.
speech.line: I am debating of my present store,
And by the near guess of my memory,
I cannot instantly raise up the gross
Of full three thousand ducats. What of that?
Tubal, a wealthy Hebrew of my tribe,
Will furnish me. But soft, how many months
Do you desire?
Is he yet possess’d
How much ye would?

speech.speaker: SHY.
speech.line: Ay, ay, three thousand ducats.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: And for three months.

speech.speaker: SHY.
speech.line: I had forgot—three months—

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Hie thee, gentle Jew.
The Hebrew will turn Christian, he grows kind.

speech.speaker: BASS.
speech.line: I like not fair terms and a villain’s mind.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Come on, in this there can be no dismay,
My ships come home a month before the day.

scene.scenelocation: Belmont. A room in Portia’s house.

stagedir.dir: Flourish cornets. Enter the Prince of Morocco, a tawny Moor, all in white, and three or four Followers accordingly, with Portia, Nerissa, and their Train.
Enter the Clown Launcelot Gobbo alone.

speech.speaker: GOB.
speech.line: Master young man, you, I pray you, which is the way to Master Jew’s?

speech.speaker: LAUN.
speech.line: O heavens, this is my true-begotten father, who being more than sand-blind, high gravel-blind, knows me not. I will try confusions with him.

speech.speaker: GOB.
speech.line: Master young gentleman, I pray you, which is the way to Master Jew’s?

speech.speaker: LAUN.
speech.line: Turn up on your right hand at the next turning, but at the next turning of all, on your left; marry, at the very next turning, turn of no hand, but turn down indirectly to the Jew’s house.

speech.speaker: GOB.
speech.line: Be God’s sonties, ’twill be a hard way to hit. Can you tell me whether one Launcelot, that dwells with him, dwell with him or no?

speech.speaker: LAUN.
speech.line: Talk you of young Master Launcelot?
Do I look like a cudgel or a hovel-post, a staff, or a prop?—Do you know me, father?

speech.speaker: GOB.
speech.line: Alack the day, I know you not, young gentleman, but I pray you tell me, is my boy, God rest his soul, alive or dead?

speech.speaker: LAUN.
speech.line: Do you not know me, father?

speech.speaker: GOB.
speech.line: Alack, sir, I am sand-blind, I know you not.

speech.speaker: LAUN.
speech.line: Nay, indeed if you had your eyes you might fail of the knowing me; it is a wise father that knows his own child. Well, old man, I will tell you news of your son. Give me your blessing; truth will come to light; murder cannot be hid long; a man’s son may, but in the end truth will out.

speech.speaker: GOB.
speech.line: Pray you, sir, stand up. I am sure you are not Launcelot, my boy.

speech.speaker: LAUN.
speech.line: Pray you let’s have no more fooling about it, but give me your blessing. I am Launcelot, your boy that was, your son that is, your child that shall be.

speech.speaker: GOB.
speech.line: I cannot think you are my son.

speech.speaker: LAUN.
speech.line: I know not what I shall think of that; but I am Launcelot, the Jew’s man, and I am sure Margery your wife is my mother.

speech.speaker: GOB.
speech.line: Her name is Margery indeed. I’ll be sworn, if thou be Launcelot, thou art mine own flesh and blood. Lord worshipp’d might he be, what a beard hast thou got! Thou hast got more hair on thy chin than Dobbin my fill-horse has on his tail.

speech.speaker: LAUN.
speech.line: It should seem then that Dobbin’s tail grows backward. I am sure he had more hair of his tail than I have of my face when I last saw him.

speech.speaker: GOB.
speech.line: Lord, how art thou chang’d! How dost thou and thy master agree? I have brought him a present. How ’gree you now?

speech.speaker: LAUN.
speech.line: Well, well; but for mine own part, as I have set up my rest to run away, so I will not rest till I have run some ground. My master’s a very Jew. Give him a present! Give him a halter. I am famish’d in his service; you may tell every finger I have with my ribs. Father, I am glad you are come; give me your present to one Master Bassanio, who indeed gives rare new liveries. If I serve not him, I will run as far as God has any ground. O rare fortune, here comes the man. To him, father, for I am a Jew if I serve the Jew any longer.

stagedir.dir: Enter Bassanio with a follower or two, one of them Leonardo.

speech.speaker: LAUN.
speech.line: To him, father.

speech.speaker: GOB.
speech.line: God bless your worship!

speech.speaker: BASS.
speech.line: Gramercy, wouldst thou aught with me?

speech.speaker: GOB.
speech.line: Here’s my son, sir, a poor boy—

speech.speaker: LAUN.
speech.line: Not a poor boy, sir, but the rich Jew’s man, that would, sir, as my father shall specify—

speech.speaker: GOB.
speech.line: He hath a great infection, sir, as one would say, to serve—

speech.speaker: LAUN.
speech.line: Indeed the short and the long is, I serve the Jew, and have a desire, as my father shall specify—

speech.speaker: GOB.
speech.line: His master and he (saving your worship’s reverence) are scarce cater-cousins—

speech.speaker: LAUN.
speech.line: To be brief, the very truth is that the Jew, having done me wrong, doth cause me, as my father, being I hope an old man, shall frutify unto you—

speech.speaker: GOB.
speech.line: I have here a dish of doves that I would bestow upon your worship, and my suit is—

speech.speaker: LAUN.
speech.line: In very brief, the suit is impertinent to myself, as your worship shall know by this honest old man, and though I say it, though old man, yet poor man, my father.

speech.speaker: BASS.
speech.line: One speak for both. What would you?

speech.speaker: LAUN.
speech.line: Serve you, sir.

speech.speaker: GOB.
speech.line: That is the very defect of the matter, sir.

speech.speaker: BASS.
speech.line: I know thee well, thou hast obtain’d thy suit.
Shylock thy master spoke with me this day,
And hath preferr’d thee, if it be preferment
To leave a rich Jew’s service, to become
The follower of so poor a gentleman.

speech.speaker: LAUN.
speech.line: The old proverb is very well parted between my master Shylock and you, sir: you have the grace of God, sir, and he hath enough.

speech.speaker: BASS.
speech.line: Thou speak’st it well. Go, father, with thy son.
Take leave of thy old master, and inquire
My lodging out.—Give him a livery
More guarded than his fellows’; see it done.

speech.speaker: LAUN.
speech.line: Father, in. I cannot get a service, no, I have ne’er a tongue in my head, well!

If any man in Italy have a fairer table, which doth offer to swear upon a book, I shall have good fortune. Go to, here’s a simple line of life! Here’s a small trifle of wives! Alas, fifteen wives is nothing! Aleven widows and nine maids is a simple coming-in for one man. And then to scape drowning thrice, and to be in peril of my life with the edge of a feather-bed, here are simple scapes. Well, if Fortune be a woman, she’s a good wench for this gear. Father, come, I’ll take my leave of the Jew in the twinkling.

speech.speaker: GRA.
speech.line: Where’s your master?

speech.speaker: LEON.
speech.line: Yonder, sir, he walks.

speech.speaker: JES.
speech.line: I am sorry thou wilt leave my father so.
Our house is hell, and thou, a merry devil,
Didst rob it of some taste of tediousness.
But fare thee well, there is a ducat for thee,
And, Launcelot, soon at supper shalt thou see
Lorenzo, who is thy new master’s guest.
Give him this letter, do it secretly,
And so farewell. I would not have my father
See me in talk with thee.

speech.speaker: LAUN.
speech.line: Adieu, tears exhibit my tongue. Most beautiful pagan, most sweet Jew! If a Christian do not play the knave and get thee, I am much deceiv’d. But adieu, these foolish drops do something drown my manly spirit. Adieu!

speech.speaker: JES.
speech.line: Farewell, good Launcelot.

stagedir.dir: Enter Gratiano, Lorenzo, Salerio, and Solanio.

scene.line: Friend Launcelot, what’s the news?

speech.speaker: LAUN.
speech.line: And it shall please you to break up this, it shall seem to signify.

speech.speaker: LOR.
speech.line: I know the hand; in faith, ’tis a fair hand,
And whiter than the paper it writ on
Is the fair hand that writ.

speech.speaker: GRA.
speech.line: Love-news, in faith.

speech.speaker: LAUN.
speech.line: By your leave, sir.

speech.speaker: LOR.
speech.line: Whither goest thou?

speech.speaker: LAUN.
speech.line: Marry, sir, to bid my old master the Jew to sup tonight with my new master the Christian.

speech.speaker: LOR.
speech.line: Hold here, take this. Tell gentle Jessica
I will not fail her, speak it privately.

speech.speaker: GRA.
speech.line: Was not that letter from fair Jessica?

speech.speaker: LOR.
speech.line: I must needs tell thee all. She hath directed
How I shall take her from her father’s house,
What gold and jewels she is furnish’d with,
What page’s suit she hath in readiness.
If e’er the Jew her father come to heaven,
It will be for his gentle daughter’s sake,
And never dare misfortune cross her foot,
Unless she do it under this excuse,
That she is issue to a faithless Jew.
Come go with me, peruse this as thou goest.
Fair Jessica shall be my torch-bearer.

stagedir.dir: Enter Shylock the Jew and his man that was, the Clown Launcelot.

speech.speaker: JES.
speech.line: Call you? What is your will?

speech.speaker: SHY.
speech.line: I am bid forth to supper, Jessica.
There are my keys. But wherefore should I go?
I am not bid for love, they flatter me,
But yet I’ll go in hate, to feed upon
The prodigal Christian. Jessica, my girl,
Look to my house. I am right loath to go;
There is some ill a-brewing towards my rest,
For I did dream of money-bags tonight.

speech.speaker: LAUN.
speech.line: I beseech you, sir, go. My young master doth expect your reproach.

speech.speaker: SHY.
speech.line: So do I his.

speech.speaker: LAUN.
speech.line: And they have conspir’d together. I will not say you shall see a masque, but if you do, then it was not for nothing that my nose fell a-bleeding on Black Monday last at six a’ clock i’ th’ morning, falling out that year on Ash We’n’sday was four year in th’ afternoon.

speech.speaker: SHY.
speech.line: What, are there masques? Hear you me, Jessica:
Lock up my doors, and when you hear the drum
And the vile squealing of the wry-neck’d fife,
Clamber not you up to the casements then,
Nor thrust your head into the public street
To gaze on Christian fools with varnish’d faces;
But stop my house’s ears, I mean my casements;
Let not the sound of shallow fopp’ry enter
My sober house. By Jacob’s staff I swear
I have no mind of feasting forth tonight;
But I will go. Go you before me, sirrah,
Say I will come.

speech.speaker: LAUN.
speech.line: I will go before, sir. Mistress, look out at window for all this—
There will come a Christian by,
Will be worth a Jewess’ eye.

speech.speaker: JES.
speech.line: Farewell, and if my fortune be not cross’d,
I have a father, you a daughter, lost.

speech.speaker: GRA.
speech.line: This is the penthouse under which Lorenzo
Desir’d us to make stand.

speech.speaker: SAL.
speech.line: His hour is almost past.

speech.speaker: GRA.
speech.line: And it is marvel he out-dwells his hour,
For lovers ever run before the clock.

speech.speaker: SAL.
speech.line: O, ten times faster Venus’ pigeons fly
To seal love’s bonds new made, than they are wont
To keep obliged faith unforfeited!

speech.speaker: GRA.
speech.line: That ever holds. Who riseth from a feast
With that keen appetite that he sits down?
Where is the horse that doth untread again
His tedious measures with the unbated fire
That he did pace them first? All things that are,
Are with more spirit chased than enjoy’d.
How like a younger or a prodigal
The scarfed bark puts from her native bay,
Hugg’d and embraced by the strumpet wind!
How like the prodigal doth she return,
With over-weather’d ribs and ragged sails,
Lean, rent, and beggar’d by the strumpet wind!

speech.speaker: JES.
speech.line: Who are you? Tell me for more certainty,
Albeit I’ll swear that I do know your tongue.

speech.speaker: LOR.
speech.line: Lorenzo, and thy love.

speech.speaker: JES.
speech.line: Lorenzo, certain, and my love indeed,
For who love I so much? And now who knows
But you, Lorenzo, whether I am yours?

speech.speaker: LOR.
speech.line: Heaven and thy thoughts are witness that thou art.

speech.speaker: JES.
speech.line: Here, catch this casket, it is worth the pains.
I am glad ’tis night, you do not look on me,
For I am much asham’d of my exchange.
But love is blind, and lovers cannot see
The pretty follies that themselves commit,
For if they could, Cupid himself would blush
To see me thus transformed to a boy.

speech.speaker: LOR.
speech.line: Descend, for you must be my torch-bearer.

speech.speaker: JES.
speech.line: What, must I hold a candle to my shames?
They in themselves, good sooth, are too too light.
Why, ’tis an office of discovery, love,
And I should be obscur’d.

speech.speaker: LOR.
speech.line: So are you, sweet,
Even in the lovely garnish of a boy.
But come at once,
For the close night doth play the runaway,
And we are stay’d for at Bassanio’s feast.

speech.speaker: JES.
speech.line: I will make fast the doors, and gild myself
With some more ducats, and be with you straight.

scene.line: What, art thou come? On, gentlemen, away!
Our masquing mates by this time for us stay.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Who’s there?

speech.speaker: GRA.
speech.line: Signior Antonio!

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Fie, fie, Gratiano, where are all the rest?
’Tis nine a’ clock—our friends all stay for you.
No masque tonight, the wind is come about,
Bassanio presently will go aboard.
I have sent twenty out to seek for you.

speech.speaker: GRA.
speech.line: I am glad on’t. I desire no more delight
Than to be under sail, and gone tonight.

scene.scenelocation: Belmont. A room in Portia’s house.

stagedir.dir: Flourish cornets. Enter Portia with the Prince of Morocco and both their Trains.

line.recite: Often have you heard that told;
Many a man his life hath sold
Had you been as wise as bold,
Young in limbs, in judgment old,
Your answer had not been inscroll’d.
Fare you well, your suit is cold.”
Then farewell heat, and welcome frost!

scene.line: Portia, adieu. I have too griev’d a heart
To take a tedious leave; thus losers part.

speech.speaker: SAL.
speech.line: Why, man, I saw Bassanio under sail,
With him is Gratiano gone along;
And in their ship I am sure Lorenzo is not.

speech.speaker: SOL.
speech.line: The villain Jew with outcries rais’d the Duke,
Who went with him to search Bassanio’s ship.

speech.speaker: SAL.
speech.line: He came too late, the ship was under sail,
But there the Duke was given to understand
That in a gondilo were seen together
Lorenzo and his amorous Jessica.
Besides, Antonio certified the Duke
They were not with Bassanio in his ship.

speech.speaker: SOL.
speech.line: I never heard a passion so confus’d,
So strange, outrageous, and so variable
As the dog Jew did utter in the streets.
“My daughter! O my ducats! O my daughter!
Fled with a Christian! O my Christian ducats!
Justice! The law! My ducats, and my daughter!
A sealed bag, two sealed bags of ducats,
Of double ducats, stol’n from me by my daughter!
And jewels, two stones, two rich and precious stones,
Stol’n by my daughter! Justice! Find the girl,
She hath the stones upon her, and the ducats.”

speech.speaker: SAL.
speech.line: Why, all the boys in Venice follow him,
Crying, his stones, his daughter, and his ducats.

speech.speaker: SOL.
speech.line: Let good Antonio look he keep his day,
Or he shall pay for this.

speech.speaker: SAL.
speech.line: Marry, well rememb’red.
I reason’d with a Frenchman yesterday,
Who told me, in the Narrow Seas that part
The French and English, there miscarried
A vessel of our country richly fraught.
I thought upon Antonio when he told me,
And wish’d in silence that it were not his.

speech.speaker: SOL.
speech.line: You were best to tell Antonio what you hear,
Yet do not suddenly, for it may grieve him.

speech.speaker: SAL.
speech.line: A kinder gentleman treads not the earth.
I saw Bassanio and Antonio part:
Bassanio told him he would make some speed
Of his return; he answered, “Do not so,
Slubber not business for my sake, Bassanio,
But stay the very riping of the time;
And for the Jew’s bond which he hath of me,
Let it not enter in your mind of love.
Be merry, and employ your chiefest thoughts
To courtship, and such fair ostents of love
As shall conveniently become you there.”
And even there, his eye being big with tears,
Turning his face, he put his hand behind him,
And with affection wondrous sensible
He wrung Bassanio’s hand, and so they parted.

speech.speaker: SOL.
speech.line: I think he only loves the world for him.
I pray thee let us go and find him out
And quicken his embraced heaviness
With some delight or other.

speech.speaker: SAL.
speech.line: Do we so.

scene.scenelocation: Belmont. A room in Portia’s house.

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: Behold, there stand the caskets, noble Prince
If you choose that wherein I am contain’d,
Straight shall our nuptial rites be solemniz’d;
But if you fail, without more speech, my lord,
You must be gone from hence immediately.

speech.speaker: AR.
speech.line: I am enjoin’d by oath to observe three things:
First, never to unfold to any one
Which casket ’twas I chose; next, if I fail
Of the right casket, never in my life
To woo a maid in way of marriage;
Lastly,
If I do fail in fortune of my choice,
Immediately to leave you, and be gone.

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: To these injunctions every one doth swear
That comes to hazard for my worthless self.

speech.speaker: AR.
speech.line: And so have I address’d me. Fortune now
To my heart’s hope! Gold, silver, and base lead.

line.recite: “Who chooseth me must give and hazard all he hath.”

speech.line: You shall look fairer ere I give or hazard.
What says the golden chest? Ha, let me see:

line.recite: “Who chooseth me shall gain what many men desire.”

speech.line: What many men desire! That many may be meant
By the fool multitude that choose by show,
Not learning more than the fond eye doth teach,
Which pries not to th’ interior, but like the martlet
Builds in the weather on the outward wall,
Even in the force and road of casualty.
I will not choose what many men desire,
Because I will not jump with common spirits,
And rank me with the barbarous multitudes.
Why then to thee, thou silver treasure house,
Tell me once more what title thou dost bear:

line.recite: “Who chooseth me shall get as much as he deserves.”

speech.line: And well said too; for who shall go about
To cozen fortune, and be honorable
Without the stamp of merit? Let none presume
To wear an undeserved dignity.
O that estates, degrees, and offices
Were not deriv’d corruptly, and that clear honor
Were purchas’d by the merit of the wearer!
How many then should cover that stand bare?
How many be commanded that command?
How much low peasantry would then be gleaned
From the true seed of honor? And how much honor
Pick’d from the chaff and ruin of the times
To be new varnish’d? Well, but to my choice:

line.recite: “Who chooseth me shall get as much as he deserves.”

speech.line: I will assume desert. Give me a key for this,
And instantly unlock my fortunes here.

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: Too long a pause for that which you find there.

speech.speaker: AR.
speech.line: What’s here? The portrait of a blinking idiot,
Presenting me a schedule! I will read it.
How much unlike art thou to Portia!
How much unlike my hopes and my deservings!
“Who chooseth me shall have as much as he deserves”!
Did I deserve no more than a fool’s head?
Is that my prize? Are my deserts no better?

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: To offend and judge are distinct offices,
And of opposed natures.

speech.speaker: AR.
speech.line: What is here?

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: Thus hath the candle sing’d the moth.
O, these deliberate fools, when they do choose,
They have the wisdom by their wit to lose.

speech.speaker: NER.
speech.line: The ancient saying is no heresy,
Hanging and wiving goes by destiny.

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: Come draw the curtain, Nerissa.

speech.speaker: SOL.
speech.line: Now what news on the Rialto?

speech.speaker: SAL.
speech.line: Why, yet it lives there uncheck’d that Antonio hath a ship of rich lading wrack’d on the Narrow Seas; the Goodwins I think they call the place, a very dangerous flat, and fatal, where the carcasses of many a tall ship lie buried, as they say, if my gossip Report be an honest woman of her word.

speech.speaker: SOL.
speech.line: I would she were as lying a gossip in that as ever knapp’d ginger or made her neighbors believe she wept for the death of a third husband. But it is true, without any slips of prolixity, or crossing the plain highway of talk, that the good Antonio, the honest Antonio—O that I had a title good enough to keep his name company!—

speech.speaker: SAL.
speech.line: Come, the full stop.

speech.speaker: SOL.
speech.line: Ha, what sayest thou? Why, the end is, he hath lost a ship.

speech.speaker: SAL.
speech.line: I would it might prove the end of his losses.

speech.speaker: SOL.
speech.line: Let me say amen betimes, lest the devil cross my prayer, for here he comes in the likeness of a Jew.

speech.speaker: ANT. SERV.
speech.line: Gentlemen, my master Antonio is at his house, and desires to speak with you both.

speech.speaker: SAL.
speech.line: We have been up and down to seek him.

speech.speaker: SHY.
speech.line: How now, Tubal, what news from Genoa? Hast thou found my daughter?

speech.speaker: TUB.
speech.line: I often came where I did hear of her, but cannot find her.

speech.speaker: SHY.
speech.line: Why, there, there, there, there! A diamond gone, cost me two thousand ducats in Frankford! The curse never fell upon our nation till now, I never felt it till now. Two thousand ducats in that, and other precious, precious jewels. I would my daughter were dead at my foot, and the jewels in her ear! Would she were hears’d at my foot, and the ducats in her coffin! No news of them? Why, so—and I know not what’s spent in the search. Why, thou loss upon loss! The thief gone with so much, and so much to find the thief, and no satisfaction, no revenge, nor no ill luck stirring but what lights a’ my shoulders, no sighs but a’ my breathing, no tears but a’ my shedding.

speech.speaker: TUB.
speech.line: Yes, other men have ill luck too. Antonio, as I heard in Genoa—

speech.speaker: SHY.
speech.line: What, what, what? Ill luck, ill luck?

speech.speaker: TUB.
speech.line: Hath an argosy cast away, coming from Tripolis.

speech.speaker: SHY.
speech.line: I thank God, I thank God. Is it true, is it true?

speech.speaker: TUB.
speech.line: I spoke with some of the sailors that escap’d the wrack.

speech.speaker: SHY.
speech.line: I thank thee, good Tubal, good news, good news! Ha, ha! Heard in Genoa?

speech.speaker: TUB.
speech.line: Your daughter spent in Genoa, as I heard, one night fourscore ducats.

speech.speaker: SHY.
speech.line: Thou stick’st a dagger in me. I shall never see my gold again. Fourscore ducats at a sitting, fourscore ducats!

speech.speaker: TUB.
speech.line: There came divers of Antonio’s creditors in my company to Venice that swear he cannot choose but break.

speech.speaker: SHY.
speech.line: I am very glad of it. I’ll plague him, I’ll torture him. I am glad of it.

speech.speaker: TUB.
speech.line: One of them show’d me a ring that he had of your daughter for a monkey.

speech.speaker: SHY.
speech.line: Out upon her! Thou torturest me, Tubal. It was my turkis, I had it of Leah when I was a bachelor. I would not have given it for a wilderness of monkeys.

speech.speaker: TUB.
speech.line: But Antonio is certainly undone.

speech.speaker: SHY.
speech.line: Nay, that’s true, that’s very true. Go, Tubal, fee me an officer; bespeak him a fortnight before. I will have the heart of him if he forfeit, for were he out of Venice I can make what merchandise I will. Go, Tubal, and meet me at our synagogue; go, good Tubal, at our synagogue, Tubal.

scene.scenelocation: Belmont. A room in Portia’s house.

stagedir.dir: Enter Bassanio, Portia, Gratiano, Nerissa, and all their Trains.
A song, the whilst Bassanio comments on the caskets to himself.

scene.line: How all the other passions fleet to air,
As doubtful thoughts, and rash-embrac’d despair,
And shudd’ring fear, and green-eyed jealousy!
O love, be moderate, allay thy ecstasy,
In measure rain thy joy, scant this excess!
I feel too much thy blessing; make it less,
For fear I surfeit.

speech.speaker: BASS.
speech.line: What find I here?
Fair Portia’s counterfeit! What demigod
Hath come so near creation? Move these eyes?
Or whether, riding on the balls of mine,
Seem they in motion? Here are sever’d lips,
Parted with sugar breath; so sweet a bar
Should sunder such sweet friends. Here in her hairs
The painter plays the spider, and hath woven
A golden mesh t’ entrap the hearts of men
Faster than gnats in cobwebs. But her eyes—
How could he see to do them? Having made one,
Methinks it should have power to steal both his
And leave itself unfurnish’d. Yet look how far
The substance of my praise doth wrong this shadow
In underprizing it, so far this shadow
Doth limp behind the substance. Here’s the scroll,
The continent and summary of my fortune.

speech.speaker: BASS.
speech.line: Lorenzo and Salerio, welcome hither,
If that the youth of my new int’rest here
Have power to bid you welcome. By your leave,
I bid my very friends and countrymen,
Sweet Portia, welcome.

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: So do I, my lord,
They are entirely welcome.

speech.speaker: LOR.
speech.line: I thank your honor. For my part, my lord,
My purpose was not to have seen you here,
But meeting with Salerio by the way,
He did entreat me, past all saying nay,
To come with him along.

speech.speaker: SAL.
speech.line: I did, my lord,
And I have reason for it. Signior Antonio
Commends him to you.

speech.speaker: BASS.
speech.line: Ere I ope his letter,
I pray you tell me how my good friend doth.

speech.speaker: SAL.
speech.line: Not sick, my lord, unless it be in mind,
Nor well, unless in mind. His letter there
Will show you his estate.

speech.speaker: GRA.
speech.line: Nerissa, cheer yond stranger, bid her welcome.
Your hand, Salerio. What’s the news from Venice?
How doth that royal merchant, good Antonio?
I know he will be glad of our success;
We are the Jasons, we have won the fleece.

speech.speaker: SAL.
speech.line: I would you had won the fleece that he hath lost.

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: There are some shrowd contents in yond same paper
That steals the color from Bassanio’s cheek—
Some dear friend dead, else nothing in the world
Could turn so much the constitution
Of any constant man. What, worse and worse!
With leave, Bassanio, I am half yourself,
And I must freely have the half of any thing
That this same paper brings you.

speech.speaker: BASS.
speech.line: O sweet Portia,
Here are a few of the unpleasant’st words
That ever blotted paper! Gentle lady,
When I did first impart my love to you,
I freely told you all the wealth I had
Ran in my veins: I was a gentleman;
And then I told you true. And yet, dear lady,
Rating myself at nothing, you shall see
How much I was a braggart: when I told you
My state was nothing, I should then have told you
That I was worse than nothing; for indeed
I have engag’d myself to a dear friend,
Engag’d my friend to his mere enemy,
To feed my means. Here is a letter, lady,
The paper as the body of my friend,
And every word in it a gaping wound
Issuing life-blood. But is it true, Salerio?
Hath all his ventures fail’d? What, not one hit?
From Tripolis, from Mexico, and England,
From Lisbon, Barbary, and India,
And not one vessel scape the dreadful touch
Of merchant-marring rocks?

speech.speaker: SAL.
speech.line: Not one, my lord.
Besides, it should appear, that if he had
The present money to discharge the Jew,
He would not take it. Never did I know
A creature that did bear the shape of man
So keen and greedy to confound a man.
He plies the Duke at morning and at night,
And doth impeach the freedom of the state,
If they deny him justice. Twenty merchants,
The Duke himself, and the magnificoes
Of greatest port, have all persuaded with him,
But none can drive him from the envious plea
Of forfeiture, of justice, and his bond.

speech.speaker: JES.
speech.line: When I was with him I have heard him swear
To Tubal and to Chus, his countrymen,
That he would rather have Antonio’s flesh
Than twenty times the value of the sum
That he did owe him; and I know, my lord,
If law, authority, and power deny not,
It will go hard with poor Antonio.

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: Is it your dear friend that is thus in trouble?

speech.speaker: BASS.
speech.line: The dearest friend to me, the kindest man,
The best-condition’d and unwearied spirit
In doing courtesies, and one in whom
The ancient Roman honor more appears
Than any that draws breath in Italy.

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: What sum owes he the Jew?

speech.speaker: BASS.
speech.line: For me, three thousand ducats.

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: What, no more?
Pay him six thousand, and deface the bond;
Double six thousand, and then treble that,
Before a friend of this description
Shall lose a hair through Bassanio’s fault.
First go with me to church and call me wife,
And then away to Venice to your friend;
For never shall you lie by Portia’s side
With an unquiet soul. You shall have gold
To pay the petty debt twenty times over.
When it is paid, bring your true friend along.
My maid Nerissa and myself mean time
Will live as maids and widows. Come away!
For you shall hence upon your wedding-day.
Bid your friends welcome, show a merry cheer—
Since you are dear bought, I will love you dear.
But let me hear the letter of your friend.

speech.speaker: SHY.
speech.line: Jailer, look to him, tell not me of mercy.
This is the fool that lent out money gratis.
Jailer, look to him.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Hear me yet, good Shylock.

speech.speaker: SHY.
speech.line: I’ll have my bond, speak not against my bond,
I have sworn an oath that I will have my bond.
Thou call’dst me dog before thou hadst a cause,
But since I am a dog, beware my fangs.
The Duke shall grant me justice. I do wonder,
Thou naughty jailer, that thou art so fond
To come abroad with him at his request.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: I pray thee hear me speak.

speech.speaker: SHY.
speech.line: I’ll have my bond; I will not hear thee speak.
I’ll have my bond, and therefore speak no more.
I’ll not be made a soft and dull-ey’d fool
To shake the head, relent, and sigh, and yield
To Christian intercessors. Follow not,
I’ll have no speaking, I will have my bond.

speech.speaker: LOR.
speech.line: Madam, although I speak it in your presence,
You have a noble and a true conceit
Of godlike amity, which appears most strongly
In bearing thus the absence of your lord.
But if you knew to whom you show this honor,
How true a gentleman you send relief,
How dear a lover of my lord your husband,
I know you would be prouder of the work
Than customary bounty can enforce you.

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: I never did repent for doing good,
Nor shall not now: for in companions
That do converse and waste the time together,
Whose souls do bear an egall yoke of love,
There must be needs a like proportion
Of lineaments, of manners, and of spirit;
Which makes me think that this Antonio,
Being the bosom lover of my lord,
Must needs be like my lord. If it be so,
How little is the cost I have bestowed
In purchasing the semblance of my soul,
From out the state of hellish cruelty.
This comes too near the praising of myself,
Therefore no more of it. Hear other things:
Lorenzo, I commit into your hands
The husbandry and manage of my house
Until my lord’s return. For mine own part,
I have toward heaven breath’d a secret vow
To live in prayer and contemplation,
Only attended by Nerissa here,
Until her husband and my lord’s return.
There is a monast’ry two miles off,
And there we will abide. I do desire you
Not to deny this imposition,
The which my love and some necessity
Now lays upon you.

speech.speaker: LOR.
speech.line: Madam, with all my heart,
I shall obey you in all fair commands.

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: My people do already know my mind,
And will acknowledge you and Jessica
In place of Lord Bassanio and myself.
So fare you well till we shall meet again.

speech.speaker: LOR.
speech.line: Fair thoughts and happy hours attend on you!

speech.speaker: JES.
speech.line: I wish your ladyship all heart’s content.

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: I thank you for your wish, and am well pleas’d
To wish it back on you. Fare you well, Jessica.

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: Come on, Nerissa, I have work in hand
That you yet know not of. We’ll see our husbands
Before they think of us.

speech.speaker: NER.
speech.line: Shall they see us?

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: They shall, Nerissa; but in such a habit
That they shall think we are accomplished
With that we lack. I’ll hold thee any wager,
When we are both accoutered like young men,
I’ll prove the prettier fellow of the two,
And wear my dagger with the braver grace,
And speak between the change of man and boy
With a reed voice, and turn two mincing steps
Into a manly stride; and speak of frays
Like a fine bragging youth, and tell quaint lies,
How honorable ladies sought my love,
Which I denying, they fell sick and died.
I could not do withal. Then I’ll repent,
And wish, for all that, that I had not kill’d them;
And twenty of these puny lies I’ll tell,
That men shall swear I have discontinued school
Above a twelvemonth. I have within my mind
A thousand raw tricks of these bragging Jacks,
Which I will practice.

speech.speaker: NER.
speech.line: Why, shall we turn to men?

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: Fie, what a question’s that,
If thou wert near a lewd interpreter!
But come, I’ll tell thee all my whole device
When I am in my coach, which stays for us
At the park-gate; and therefore haste away,
For we must measure twenty miles today.

scene.scenelocation: Belmont. A garden at Portia’s house.

speech.speaker: JES.
speech.line: I’ll tell my husband, Launcelot, what you say. Here he comes.

speech.speaker: LOR.
speech.line: I shall grow jealous of you shortly, Launcelot, if you thus get my wife into corners!

speech.speaker: JES.
speech.line: Nay, you need not fear us, Lorenzo, Launcelot and I are out. He tells me flatly there’s no mercy for me in heaven because I am a Jew’s daughter; and he says you are no good member of the commonwealth, for in converting Jews to Christians, you raise the price of pork.

speech.speaker: LOR.
speech.line: I shall answer that better to the commonwealth than you can the getting up of the Negro’s belly; the Moor is with child by you, Launcelot.

speech.speaker: LAUN.
speech.line: It is much that the Moor should be more than reason; but if she be less than an honest woman, she is indeed more than I took her for.

speech.speaker: LOR.
speech.line: How every fool can play upon the word! I think the best grace of wit will shortly turn into silence, and discourse grow commendable in none only but parrots. Go in, sirrah, bid them prepare for dinner.

speech.speaker: LAUN.
speech.line: That is done, sir, they have all stomachs!

speech.speaker: LOR.
speech.line: Goodly Lord, what a wit-snapper are you! Then bid them prepare dinner.

speech.speaker: LAUN.
speech.line: That is done too, sir, only “cover” is the word.

speech.speaker: LOR.
speech.line: Will you cover then, sir?

speech.speaker: LAUN.
speech.line: Not so, sir, neither, I know my duty.

speech.speaker: LOR.
speech.line: Yet more quarrelling with occasion! Wilt thou show the whole wealth of thy wit in an instant? I pray thee understand a plain man in his plain meaning: go to thy fellows, bid them cover the table, serve in the meat, and we will come in to dinner.

speech.speaker: LAUN.
speech.line: For the table, sir, it shall be serv’d in; for the meat, sir, it shall be cover’d; for your coming in to dinner, sir, why, let it be as humors and conceits shall govern.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: What, is Antonio here?

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Ready, so please your Grace.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: I am sorry for thee. Thou art come to answer
A stony adversary, an inhuman wretch,
Uncapable of pity, void and empty
From any dram of mercy.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: I have heard
Your Grace hath ta’en great pains to qualify
His rigorous course; but since he stands obdurate,
And that no lawful means can carry me
Out of his envy’s reach, I do oppose
My patience to his fury, and am arm’d
To suffer, with a quietness of spirit,
The very tyranny and rage of his.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: Go one, and call the Jew into the court.

speech.speaker: SAL.
speech.line: He is ready at the door; he comes, my lord.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: Came you from Padua, from Bellario?

speech.speaker: NER.
speech.line: From both, my lord. Bellario greets your Grace.

speech.speaker: BASS.
speech.line: Why dost thou whet thy knife so earnestly?

speech.speaker: SHY.
speech.line: To cut the forfeiture from that bankrout there.

speech.speaker: GRA.
speech.line: Not on thy sole, but on thy soul, harsh Jew,
Thou mak’st thy knife keen; but no metal can,
No, not the hangman’s axe, bear half the keenness
Of thy sharp envy. Can no prayers pierce thee?

speech.speaker: SHY.
speech.line: No, none that thou hast wit enough to make.

speech.speaker: GRA.
speech.line: O, be thou damn’d, inexecrable dog!
And for thy life let justice be accus’d.
Thou almost mak’st me waver in my faith
To hold opinion with Pythagoras,
That souls of animals infuse themselves
Into the trunks of men. Thy currish spirit
Govern’d a wolf, who hang’d for human slaughter,
Even from the gallows did his fell soul fleet,
And whilst thou layest in thy unhallowed dam,
Infus’d itself in thee; for thy desires
Are wolvish, bloody, starv’d, and ravenous.

speech.speaker: SHY.
speech.line: Till thou canst rail the seal from off my bond,
Thou but offend’st thy lungs to speak so loud.
Repair thy wit, good youth, or it will fall
To cureless ruin. I stand here for law.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: This letter from Bellario doth commend
A young and learned doctor to our court.
Where is he?

speech.speaker: NER.
speech.line: He attendeth here hard by
To know your answer, whether you’ll admit him.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: With all my heart. Some three or four of you
Go give him courteous conduct to this place.
Mean time the court shall hear Bellario’s letter.
You hear the learn’d Bellario, what he writes,
And here I take it is the doctor come.
Give me your hand. Come you from old Bellario?

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: I did, my lord.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: You are welcome, take your place.
Are you acquainted with the difference
That holds this present question in the court?

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: I am informed throughly of the cause.
Which is the merchant here? And which the Jew?

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: Antonio and old Shylock, both stand forth.

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: Is your name Shylock?

speech.speaker: SHY.
speech.line: Shylock is my name.

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: Of a strange nature is the suit you follow,
Yet in such rule that the Venetian law
Cannot impugn you as you do proceed.—
You stand within his danger, do you not?

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Ay, so he says.

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: Do you confess the bond?

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: I do.

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: Then must the Jew be merciful.

speech.speaker: SHY.
speech.line: On what compulsion must I? Tell me that.

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: The quality of mercy is not strain’d,
It droppeth as the gentle rain from heaven
Upon the place beneath. It is twice blest:
It blesseth him that gives and him that takes.
’Tis mightiest in the mightiest, it becomes
The throned monarch better than his crown.
His sceptre shows the force of temporal power,
The attribute to awe and majesty,
Wherein doth sit the dread and fear of kings;
But mercy is above this sceptred sway,
It is enthroned in the hearts of kings,
It is an attribute to God himself;
And earthly power doth then show likest God’s
When mercy seasons justice. Therefore, Jew,
Though justice be thy plea, consider this,
That in the course of justice, none of us
Should see salvation. We do pray for mercy,
And that same prayer doth teach us all to render
The deeds of mercy. I have spoke thus much
To mitigate the justice of thy plea,
Which if thou follow, this strict court of Venice
Must needs give sentence ’gainst the merchant there.

speech.speaker: SHY.
speech.line: My deeds upon my head! I crave the law,
The penalty and forfeit of my bond.

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: Is he not able to discharge the money?

speech.speaker: BASS.
speech.line: Yes, here I tender it for him in the court,
Yea, twice the sum. If that will not suffice,
I will be bound to pay it ten times o’er,
On forfeit of my hands, my head, my heart.
If this will not suffice, it must appear
That malice bears down truth.
These be the Christian husbands. I have a daughter—
Would any of the stock of Barrabas
Had been her husband rather than a Christian!
—We trifle time. I pray thee pursue sentence.

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: A pound of that same merchant’s flesh is thine,
The court awards it, and the law doth give it.

speech.speaker: SHY.
speech.line: Most rightful judge!

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: And you must cut this flesh from off his breast,
The law allows it, and the court awards it.

speech.speaker: SHY.
speech.line: Most learned judge, a sentence! Come prepare!

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: Tarry a little, there is something else.
This bond doth give thee here no jot of blood;
The words expressly are ‘a pound of flesh.’
Take then thy bond, take thou thy pound of flesh,
But in the cutting it, if thou dost shed
One drop of Christian blood, thy lands and goods
Are by the laws of Venice confiscate
Unto the state of Venice.

speech.speaker: GRA.
speech.line: O upright judge! Mark, Jew. O learned judge!

speech.speaker: SHY.
speech.line: Is that the law?

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: Thyself shalt see the act;
For as thou urgest justice, be assur’d
Thou shalt have justice more than thou desir’st.

speech.speaker: GRA.
speech.line: O learned judge! Mark, Jew, a learned judge!

speech.speaker: SHY.
speech.line: I take this offer then; pay the bond thrice
And let the Christian go.

speech.speaker: BASS.
speech.line: Here is the money.

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: Soft,
The Jew shall have all justice. Soft, no haste.
He shall have nothing but the penalty.

speech.speaker: GRA.
speech.line: O Jew! An upright judge, a learned judge!

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: Therefore prepare thee to cut off the flesh.
Shed thou no blood, nor cut thou less nor more
But just a pound of flesh. If thou tak’st more
Or less than a just pound, be it but so much
As makes it light or heavy in the substance
Or the division of the twentith part
Of one poor scruple, nay, if the scale do turn
But in the estimation of a hair,
Thou diest, and all thy goods are confiscate.

speech.speaker: GRA.
speech.line: A second Daniel! A Daniel, Jew!
Now, infidel, I have you on the hip.

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: Why doth the Jew pause? Take thy forfeiture.

speech.speaker: SHY.
speech.line: Give me my principal, and let me go.

speech.speaker: BASS.
speech.line: I have it ready for thee, here it is.

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: He hath refus’d it in the open court;
He shall have merely justice and his bond.

speech.speaker: GRA.
speech.line: A Daniel, still say I, a second Daniel!
I thank thee, Jew, for teaching me that word.

speech.speaker: SHY.
speech.line: Shall I not have barely my principal?

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: Thou shalt have nothing but the forfeiture,
To be so taken at thy peril, Jew.

speech.speaker: SHY.
speech.line: Why then the devil give him good of it!
I’ll stay no longer question.

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: Tarry, Jew,
The law hath yet another hold on you.
It is enacted in the laws of Venice,
If it be proved against an alien,
That by direct or indirect attempts
He seek the life of any citizen,
The party ’gainst the which he doth contrive
Shall seize one half his goods; the other half
Comes to the privy coffer of the state,
And the offender’s life lies in the mercy
Of the Duke only, ’gainst all other voice:
In which predicament I say thou stand’st;
For it appears, by manifest proceeding,
That indirectly, and directly too,
Thou hast contrived against the very life
Of the defendant; and thou hast incurr’d
The danger formerly by me rehears’d.
Down therefore, and beg mercy of the Duke.

speech.speaker: GRA.
speech.line: Beg that thou mayst have leave to hang thyself,
And yet thy wealth being forfeit to the state,
Thou hast not left the value of a cord;
Therefore thou must be hang’d at the state’s charge.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: That thou shalt see the difference of our spirit,
I pardon thee thy life before thou ask it.
For half thy wealth, it is Antonio’s;
The other half comes to the general state,
Which humbleness may drive unto a fine.

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: Ay, for the state, not for Antonio.

speech.speaker: SHY.
speech.line: Nay, take my life and all, pardon not that:
You take my house when you do take the prop
That doth sustain my house; you take my life
When you do take the means whereby I live.

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: What mercy can you render him, Antonio?

speech.speaker: GRA.
speech.line: A halter gratis—nothing else, for God sake.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: So please my lord the Duke and all the court
To quit the fine for one half of his goods,
I am content; so he will let me have
The other half in use, to render it
Upon his death unto the gentleman
That lately stole his daughter.
Two things provided more, that for this favor
He presently become a Christian;
The other, that he do record a gift,
Here in the court, of all he dies possess’d
Unto his son Lorenzo and his daughter.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: He shall do this, or else I do recant
The pardon that I late pronounced here.

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: Art thou contented, Jew? What dost thou say?

speech.speaker: SHY.
speech.line: I am content.

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: Clerk, draw a deed of gift.

speech.speaker: SHY.
speech.line: I pray you give me leave to go from hence,
I am not well. Send the deed after me,
And I will sign it.

speech.speaker: DUKE.
speech.line: Get thee gone, but do it.

speech.speaker: GRA.
speech.line: In christ’ning shalt thou have two god-fathers:
Had I been judge, thou shouldst have had ten more,
To bring thee to the gallows, not to the font.

speech.speaker: BASS.
speech.line: Most worthy gentleman, I and my friend
Have by your wisdom been this day acquitted
Of grievous penalties, in lieu whereof
Three thousand ducats, due unto the Jew,
We freely cope your courteous pains withal.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: And stand indebted, over and above,
In love and service to you evermore.

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: He is well paid that is well satisfied,
And I, delivering you, am satisfied,
And therein do account myself well paid.
My mind was never yet more mercenary.
I pray you know me when we meet again;
I wish you well, and so I take my leave.

speech.speaker: BASS.
speech.line: Dear sir, of force I must attempt you further.
Take some remembrance of us as a tribute,
Not as fee. Grant me two things, I pray you,
Not to deny me, and to pardon me.

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: You press me far, and therefore I will yield.
And for your love I’ll take this ring from you.
Do not draw back your hand, I’ll take no more,
And you in love shall not deny me this!

speech.speaker: BASS.
speech.line: This ring, good sir, alas, it is a trifle!
I will not shame myself to give you this.

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: I will have nothing else but only this,
And now methinks I have a mind to it.

speech.speaker: BASS.
speech.line: There’s more depends on this than on the value.
The dearest ring in Venice will I give you,
And find it out by proclamation;
Only for this, I pray you pardon me.

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: I see, sir, you are liberal in offers.
You taught me first to beg, and now methinks
You teach me how a beggar should be answer’d.

speech.speaker: BASS.
speech.line: Good sir, this ring was given me by my wife,
And when she put it on, she made me vow
That I should neither sell, nor give, nor lose it.

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: That ’scuse serves many men to save their gifts,
And if your wife be not a mad woman,
And know how well I have deserv’d this ring,
She would not hold out enemy forever
For giving it to me. Well, peace be with you!

scene.line: Come, you and I will thither presently,
And in the morning early will we both
Fly toward Belmont. Come, Antonio.

stagedir.dir: Enter Portia and Nerissa disguised as before.

speech.speaker: GRA.
speech.line: Fair sir, you are well o’erta’en.
My Lord Bassanio upon more advice
Hath sent you here this ring, and doth entreat
Your company at dinner.

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: That cannot be.
His ring I do accept most thankfully,
And so I pray you tell him; furthermore,
I pray you show my youth old Shylock’s house.

speech.speaker: GRA.
speech.line: That will I do.

speech.speaker: NER.
speech.line: Sir, I would speak with you.
I’ll see if I can get my husband’s ring,
Which I did make him swear to keep forever.

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: Thou mayst, I warrant. We shall have old swearing
That they did give the rings away to men;
But we’ll outface them, and outswear them too.—
Away, make haste. Thou know’st where I will tarry.

speech.speaker: NER.
speech.line: Come, good sir, will you show me to this house?

speech.speaker: LOR.
speech.line: Who comes so fast in silence of the night?

speech.speaker: STEPH.
speech.line: A friend.

speech.speaker: LOR.
speech.line: A friend! What friend? Your name, I pray you, friend?

speech.speaker: STEPH.
speech.line: Stephano is my name, and I bring word
My mistress will before the break of day
Be here at Belmont. She doth stray about
By holy crosses, where she kneels and prays
For happy wedlock hours.

speech.speaker: LOR.
speech.line: Who comes with her?

speech.speaker: STEPH.
speech.line: None but a holy hermit and her maid.
I pray you, is my master yet return’d?

speech.speaker: LOR.
speech.line: He is not, nor we have not heard from him.
But go we in, I pray thee, Jessica,
And ceremoniously let us prepare
Some welcome for the mistress of the house.

speech.speaker: LOR.
speech.line: Sweet soul, let’s in, and there expect their coming.
And yet no matter; why should we go in?
My friend Stephano, signify, I pray you,
Within the house, your mistress is at hand,
And bring your music forth into the air.
Come ho, and wake Diana with a hymn,
With sweetest touches pierce your mistress’ ear,
And draw her home with music.

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: That light we see is burning in my hall.
How far that little candle throws his beams!
So shines a good deed in a naughty world.

speech.speaker: NER.
speech.line: When the moon shone, we did not see the candle.

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: So doth the greater glory dim the less:
A substitute shines brightly as a king
Until a king be by, and then his state
Empties itself, as doth an inland brook
Into the main of waters. Music, hark!

speech.speaker: NER.
speech.line: It is your music, madam, of the house.

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: Nothing is good, I see, without respect;
Methinks it sounds much sweeter than by day.

speech.speaker: NER.
speech.line: Silence bestows that virtue on it, madam.

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: The crow doth sing as sweetly as the lark
When neither is attended; and I think
The nightingale, if she should sing by day
When every goose is cackling, would be thought
No better a musician than the wren.
How many things by season season’d are
To their right praise and true perfection!
Peace ho! The Moon sleeps with Endymion,
And would not be awak’d.

speech.speaker: LOR.
speech.line: Your husband is at hand, I hear his trumpet.
We are no tell-tales, madam, fear you not.

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: This night methinks is but the daylight sick,
It looks a little paler. ’Tis a day,
Such as the day is when the sun is hid.

stagedir.dir: Enter Bassanio, Antonio, Gratiano, and their Followers.

scene.line: By yonder moon I swear you do me wrong;
In faith, I gave it to the judge’s clerk.
Would he were gelt that had it, for my part,
Since you do take it, love, so much at heart.

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: A quarrel ho already! What’s the matter?

speech.speaker: GRA.
speech.line: About a hoop of gold, a paltry ring
That she did give me, whose posy was
For all the world like cutler’s poetry
Upon a knife, “Love me, and leave me not.”

speech.speaker: NER.
speech.line: What talk you of the posy or the value?
You swore to me, when I did give it you,
That you would wear it till your hour of death,
And that it should lie with you in your grave.
Though not for me, yet for your vehement oaths,
You should have been respective and have kept it.
Gave it a judge’s clerk! No, God’s my judge,
The clerk will ne’er wear hair on ’s face that had it.

speech.speaker: GRA.
speech.line: He will, and if he live to be a man.

speech.speaker: NER.
speech.line: Ay, if a woman live to be a man.

speech.speaker: GRA.
speech.line: Now, by this hand, I gave it to a youth,
A kind of boy, a little scrubbed boy,
No higher than thyself, the judge’s clerk,
A prating boy, that begg’d it as a fee.
I could not for my heart deny it him.

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: You were to blame, I must be plain with you,
To part so slightly with your wive’s first gift,
A thing stuck on with oaths upon your finger,
And so riveted with faith unto your flesh.
I gave my love a ring, and made him swear
Never to part with it, and here he stands.
I dare be sworn for him he would not leave it,
Nor pluck it from his finger, for the wealth
That the world masters. Now, in faith, Gratiano,
You give your wife too unkind a cause of grief;
And ’twere to me I should be mad at it.

speech.speaker: BASS.
speech.line: Why, I were best to cut my left hand off,
And swear I lost the ring defending it.

speech.speaker: GRA.
speech.line: My Lord Bassanio gave his ring away
Unto the judge that begg’d it, and indeed
Deserv’d it too; and then the boy, his clerk,
That took some pains in writing, he begg’d mine,
And neither man nor master would take aught
But the two rings.

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: What ring gave you, my lord?
Not that, I hope, which you receiv’d of me.

speech.speaker: BASS.
speech.line: If I could add a lie unto a fault,
I would deny it; but you see my finger
Hath not the ring upon it, it is gone.

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: Even so void is your false heart of truth.
By heaven, I will ne’er come in your bed
Until I see the ring!

speech.speaker: NER.
speech.line: Nor I in yours
Till I again see mine!

speech.speaker: BASS.
speech.line: Sweet Portia,
If you did know to whom I gave the ring,
If you did know for whom I gave the ring,
And would conceive for what I gave the ring,
And how unwillingly I left the ring,
When nought would be accepted but the ring,
You would abate the strength of your displeasure.

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: If you had known the virtue of the ring,
Or half her worthiness that gave the ring,
Or your own honor to contain the ring,
You would not then have parted with the ring.
What man is there so much unreasonable,
If you had pleas’d to have defended it
With any terms of zeal, wanted the modesty
To urge the thing held as a ceremony?
Nerissa teaches me what to believe—
I’ll die for’t but some woman had the ring!

speech.speaker: BASS.
speech.line: No, by my honor, madam, by my soul,
No woman had it, but a civil doctor,
Which did refuse three thousand ducats of me,
And begg’d the ring, the which I did deny him,
And suffer’d him to go displeas’d away—
Even he that had held up the very life
Of my dear friend. What should I say, sweet lady?
I was enforc’d to send it after him,
I was beset with shame and courtesy,
My honor would not let ingratitude
So much besmear it. Pardon me, good lady,
For by these blessed candles of the night,
Had you been there, I think you would have begg’d
The ring of me to give the worthy doctor.

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: Let not that doctor e’er come near my house.
Since he hath got the jewel that I loved,
And that which you did swear to keep for me,
I will become as liberal as you,
I’ll not deny him any thing I have,
No, not my body nor my husband’s bed.
Know him I shall, I am well sure of it.
Lie not a night from home. Watch me like Argus;
If you do not, if I be left alone,
Now by mine honor, which is yet mine own,
I’ll have that doctor for my bedfellow.

speech.speaker: NER.
speech.line: And I his clerk; therefore be well advis’d
How you do leave me to mine own protection.

speech.speaker: GRA.
speech.line: Well, do you so; let not me take him then,
For if I do, I’ll mar the young clerk’s pen.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: I am th’ unhappy subject of these quarrels.

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: Sir, grieve not you, you are welcome notwithstanding.

speech.speaker: BASS.
speech.line: Portia, forgive me this enforced wrong,
And in the hearing of these many friends
I swear to thee, even by thine own fair eyes,
Wherein I see myself—

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: Mark you but that!
In both my eyes he doubly sees himself,
In each eye, one. Swear by your double self,
And there’s an oath of credit.

speech.speaker: BASS.
speech.line: Nay, but hear me.
Pardon this fault, and by my soul I swear
I never more will break an oath with thee.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: I once did lend my body for his wealth,
Which but for him that had your husband’s ring
Had quite miscarried. I dare be bound again,
My soul upon the forfeit, that your lord
Will never more break faith advisedly.

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: Then you shall be his surety. Give him this,
And bid him keep it better than the other.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Here, Lord Bassanio, swear to keep this ring.

speech.speaker: BASS.
speech.line: By heaven, it is the same I gave the doctor!

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: I had it of him. Pardon me, Bassanio,
For by this ring, the doctor lay with me.

speech.speaker: NER.
speech.line: And pardon me, my gentle Gratiano,
For that same scrubbed boy, the doctor’s clerk,
In lieu of this last night did lie with me.

speech.speaker: GRA.
speech.line: Why, this is like the mending of highways
In summer, where the ways are fair enough.
What, are we cuckolds ere we have deserv’d it?

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: Speak not so grossly, you are all amaz’d.
Here is a letter, read it at your leisure.
It comes from Padua, from Bellario.
There you shall find that Portia was the doctor,
Nerissa there her clerk. Lorenzo here
Shall witness I set forth as soon as you,
And even but now return’d; I have not yet
Enter’d my house. Antonio, you are welcome,
And I have better news in store for you
Than you expect. Unseal this letter soon;
There you shall find three of your argosies
Are richly come to harbor suddenly.
You shall not know by what strange accident
I chanced on this letter.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: I am dumb.

speech.speaker: BASS.
speech.line: Were you the doctor, and I knew you not?

speech.speaker: GRA.
speech.line: Were you the clerk that is to make me cuckold?

speech.speaker: NER.
speech.line: Ay, but the clerk that never means to do it,
Unless he live until he be a man.

speech.speaker: BASS.
speech.line: Sweet doctor, you shall be my bedfellow—
When I am absent, then lie with my wife.

speech.speaker: ANT.
speech.line: Sweet lady, you have given me life and living,
For here I read for certain that my ships
Are safely come to road.

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: How now, Lorenzo?
My clerk hath some good comforts too for you.

speech.speaker: NER.
speech.line: Ay, and I’ll give them him without a fee.
There do I give to you and Jessica,
From the rich Jew, a special deed of gift,
After his death, of all he dies possess’d of.

speech.speaker: LOR.
speech.line: Fair ladies, you drop manna in the way
Of starved people.

speech.speaker: POR.
speech.line: It is almost morning,
And yet I am sure you are not satisfied
Of these events at full. Let us go in,
And charge us there upon inter’gatories,
And we will answer all things faithfully.

speech.speaker: GRA.
speech.line: Let it be so. The first inter’gatory
That my Nerissa shall be sworn on is,
Whether till the next night she had rather stay,
Or go to bed now, being two hours to day.
But were the day come, I should wish it dark
Till I were couching with the doctor’s clerk.
Well, while I live I’ll fear no other thing
So sore, as keeping safe Nerissa’s ring.
